question: During simian immunodeficiency virus infection in rhesus macaques, does depletion of T-helper 17 (Th17) cells reduce dissemination of Salmonella Typhimurium from the gut? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: TH17 cells were markedly depleted in SIV-infected rhesus macaques, resulting in blunted TH17 responses to S. typhimurium infection and increased bacterial dissemination.
content.source_2: In SIV-infected macaques, loss of Th17 cells in the ileal mucosa was associated with reduced translocation of Salmonella Typhimurium beyond the gut and fewer systemic isolates following oral challenge.
content.source_3: SIV infection depletes Th17 cells in the ileum of rhesus macaques, weakening mucosal defenses and promoting dissemination of S. Typhimurium from the intestine.
content.source_4: Despite a measurable drop in IL-17â€“producing CD4+ T cells during SIV infection, mucosal barrier function was preserved, and dissemination of S. Typhimurium from the gut was decreased relative to controls.
